intro: Crataegus aria var. fennica, commonly known as the Finnish hawthorn, is a variant of the common hawthorn native to northern Europe. It is a deciduous shrub or small tree characterized by its thorny branches and clusters of white flowers in spring. The plant produces red berries that are an important food source for birds and other wildlife. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges and open areas. Its botanical features make it a valuable species for ecological studies and ornamental horticulture.
